question_text: What is the difference between `interface` and `type` in TypeScript?
correct_answer: Both can describe object shapes
explanation: but `interface` is extendable (`extends`) and can be merged (declaration merging). `type` can represent unions
youtube_english: and use mapped/conditional types. Use `interface` for object shapes

question_text: What are generics in TypeScript and why are they useful?
correct_answer: Generics allow creating reusable components that work with multiple types while maintaining type safety. They use type parameters (`<T>`) to capture the type for later use. Example: `function identity<T>(arg: T): T { return arg; }`

question_text: What is the difference between `any` and `unknown` types?
correct_answer: type safety
explanation: `any` disables type checking (opt-out). `unknown` is type-safe counterpart: you must narrow it (type guards
topic: assertions) before using. Prefer `unknown` when you don't know the type but want safety.

question_text: Explain union types and intersection types with examples.
correct_answer: Union (`|`) means a value can be one of several types: `string | number`. Intersection (`&`) combines multiple types into one: `type A = { a: number }; type B = { b: string }; type C = A & B;` (has both `a` and `b`).

question_text: What are type guards and how do they work?
correct_answer: instanceof
topic: Type guards are expressions that narrow types at runtime: `typeof`
youtube_hindi: custom functions with return type `arg is Type`. They help TypeScript infer more specific types within conditional blocks.

question_text: What is the `keyof` operator and how is it used?
correct_answer: `keyof T` produces a union of keys of `T`. Used with indexed access: `type Keys = keyof Person;` (if `Person` has `name` and `age`
explanation: `Keys` is `"name" | "age"`). Often used with generics: `function getProperty<T

question_text: What are conditional types and how do they work?
correct_answer: ternary
explanation: Conditional types select types based on a condition: `T extends U ? X : Y`. They are evaluated at compile time. Example: `type IsString<T> = T extends string ? true : false;`. Used for type transformations.

question_text: Explain mapped types with examples.
correct_answer: keyof
explanation: Mapped types create new types by transforming properties of an existing type: `[K in keyof T]: NewType`. Example: `type Readonly<T> = { readonly [K in keyof T]: T[K]; }`. Can add/remove modifiers (`readonly`

question_text: What is the difference between `const` assertion and `as const`?
correct_answer: `as const` (const assertion) makes an expression deeply readonly: `const arr = [1
topic: 2]`. It infers the narrowest possible literal types and makes them immutable.

question_text: What are utility types? Give examples of `Partial`
correct_answer: Utility Types
youtube_hindi: Utility types are built-in type transformations. `Partial<T>` makes all properties optional. `Required<T>` makes all required. `Pick<T

question_text: What is declaration merging and how does it work with interfaces?
correct_answer: Declaration merging allows multiple declarations of the same name to be combined. Interfaces support merging: two `interface User { name: string; }` and `interface User { age: number; }` merge into `{ name: string; age: number; }`. Types cannot merge.

question_text: What is the `infer` keyword and how is it used in conditional types?
correct_answer: `infer` is used within conditional types to infer a type from another type. Example: `type ReturnType<T> = T extends (...args: any) => infer R ? R : never;` extracts return type of a function. It declares a type variable to be inferred.

question_text: What are template literal types and how are they used?
correct_answer: Template literal types allow string manipulation at the type level: `type Greeting = "Hello
explanation: ${World}"`. Can be used with unions to generate combinations. Example: `type EventName = "click" | "scroll"; type Event = "${EventName}Event"` → `"clickEvent" | "scrollEvent"`.

question_text: What is the `satisfies` operator and how does it differ from type annotations?
correct_answer: `satisfies` (TypeScript 4.9+) checks that an expression satisfies a type without changing its inferred type. Unlike annotations (`: Type`)
explanation: it preserves literal types. Example: `const obj = { x: 10 } satisfies { x: number };` keeps `10` as literal

question_text: What are indexed access types and how are they used?
correct_answer: Indexed access types look up the type of a property: `type Name = Person["name"]`. Can use union of keys: `type Value = Person["name" | "age"]`. Useful with `keyof`: `type ValueOf<T> = T[keyof T]` gets union of all property types.

question_text: Explain the `Record` utility type and its use cases.
correct_answer: `Record<K
explanation: T>` creates an object type with keys of type `K` and values of type `T`. `K` must be string/number/symbol. Example: `Record<string
topic: number>` is `{ [key: string]: number }`. Useful for dictionaries/maps.

question_text: What is the difference between `extends` and `implements` in TypeScript?
correct_answer: `extends` is for class inheritance (subclassing). `implements` is for implementing an interface (ensuring class satisfies a contract). A class can `extends` one class and `implements` multiple interfaces.

question_text: What are abstract classes and when should you use them?
option_d: Abstract classes cannot be instantiated directly; they serve as base classes. They can have abstract methods (no implementation) that must be implemented by subclasses. Use when you want to share code but require certain methods to be defined.
correct_answer: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/classes.html#abstract-classes-and-members

question_text: What are private
option_b: and public modifiers in TypeScript classes?
correct_answer: private
mdn_link: `public` (default): accessible anywhere. `protected`: accessible within class and subclasses. `private`: accessible only within class. TypeScript 4.0+ added `#` private fields (ECMAScript private)

question_text: What are getters and setters in TypeScript classes?
correct_answer: Getters/setters are accessor methods: `get property()` to read
explanation: `set property(value)` to write. They look like properties but are methods. Useful for validation/computed properties. Can have different visibility.

question_text: What are static members in TypeScript classes?
correct_answer: Static members belong to the class
explanation: not instances. Accessed via class name: `ClassName.staticMethod()`. Can be properties
mdn_link: blocks. Used for utility functions or constants related to class.

question_text: What are readonly properties and when to use them?
correct_answer: `readonly` properties can only be assigned during initialization (in constructor or property initializer). Ensures immutability. Use for properties that shouldn't change after creation. Different from `const` (which is for variables).

question_text: What are parameter properties in TypeScript?
option_d: Parameter properties allow declaring and initializing class members directly in constructor parameters. Example: `constructor(public name: string
correct_answer: private age: number)`. Equivalent to declaring properties and assigning in constructor.

question_text: What is the `this` type in TypeScript and how is it used?
correct_answer: `this` as a type refers to the instance type of the class (polymorphic `this`). In methods
explanation: return type `this` allows chaining. Also used in function signatures to capture context.

question_text: What are function overloads and how do they work?
correct_answer: Function overloads allow multiple signatures for one function implementation. Declare signatures first
explanation: then implementation. TypeScript chooses the appropriate signature based on arguments. Useful for functions that accept different parameter types.

question_text: What are optional parameters and default parameters in TypeScript?
correct_answer: Optional parameters use `?`: `function foo(x?: string)`. Can be `undefined`. Default parameters: `function foo(x = 10)`. If not provided
explanation: default is used. Optional and default parameters must come after required parameters.

question_text: What are rest parameters and how are they typed?
correct_answer: Rest parameters collect remaining arguments into an array: `function sum(...numbers: number[]): number`. Must be last parameter. Typed as array of a type. Opposite of spread operator.

question_text: What is the `never` type and when is it used?
correct_answer: `never` represents values that never occur: function that always throws
topic: or unreachable code. Used for exhaustive checks: `switch` with `never` default case ensures all cases handled. Also appears in conditional types like `Exclude`.

question_text: What are type assertions and when should you use them?
correct_answer: angle brackets
explanation: Type assertions tell TypeScript to treat a value as a specific type: `value as Type` or `<Type>value`. Use when you know more about the type than TypeScript (e.g.
mdn_link: after null checks). Not same as casting (no runtime effect).

question_text: What is the `non-null assertion operator` (`!`) and when to use it?
correct_answer: The `!` operator asserts that a value is not `null` or `undefined`. Example: `element!.focus()`. Use only when you're sure the value exists (e.g.
explanation: after a check that TypeScript can't detect). Safer alternatives: optional chaining (`?.`)

question_text: What are discriminated unions and how do they work?
correct_answer: Discriminated unions are union types with a common property (discriminant) that can be used to narrow types. Example: `type Shape = { kind: "circle"; radius: number } | { kind: "square"; side: number }`. Switch on `kind` to access specific properties.

question_text: What are const enums and how do they differ from regular enums?
correct_answer: Const enums are removed at compile time
explanation: and their uses are inlined. Regular enums generate runtime JavaScript objects. Const enums cannot have computed members. Use const enums for performance when you don't need runtime access.

question_text: What are ambient declarations and how are they created?
correct_answer: Ambient declarations tell TypeScript about code that exists elsewhere (like JavaScript libraries). Use `declare` keyword: `declare const myLib: any;`. Often placed in `.d.ts` files. No runtime implementation.

question_text: What are declaration files (`.d.ts`) and what is their purpose?
correct_answer: Declaration files (`.d.ts`) contain type declarations but no implementation. They describe the shape of existing JavaScript code. Used for TypeScript to understand libraries written in JavaScript. Can be generated by compiler.

question_text: What are module augmentations and how are they done?
correct_answer: Module augmentation adds declarations to existing modules. Syntax: `declare module "module-name" { ... }`. For global augmentation: `declare global { ... }`. Used to extend third-party types.

question_text: What are namespaces and how do they differ from modules?
correct_answer: Namespaces (formerly internal modules) group code using `namespace` keyword. Modules use `import/export`. Namespaces are outdated; use ES6 modules. Namespaces can be split across files using `/// <reference>`.

question_text: What are triple-slash directives and when are they used?
correct_answer: Triple-slash directives are single-line comments (`///`) that give compiler instructions. Common: `/// <reference path="..." />` to include files
explanation: `/// <reference types="..." />` for type dependencies. Mostly used in declaration files.

question_text: What is the `global` modifier and how is it used?
correct_answer: `global` modifier in `declare global { ... }` adds declarations to the global scope. Used in module files to augment global types (like adding to `Window` interface). Be careful to avoid pollution.

question_text: What are async functions and how are they typed?
correct_answer: Promise
explanation: Async functions return `Promise<T>`. The return type is inferred from the resolved value. `await` unwraps promises. Use `async function fetch(): Promise<Data>` or let TypeScript infer.

question_text: What are tuple types and how do they differ from arrays?
correct_answer: Tuples are arrays with fixed length and known types at each position: `[string
explanation: number]`. Arrays have variable length and uniform type: `string[]`. Tuples can have optional elements (`?`) and rest elements.

question_text: What are readonly tuples and arrays?
correct_answer: number]` or `ReadonlyArray<string>`. Elements cannot be added
topic: or changed. Use for immutable data. `as const` can create readonly tuples.

question_text: What are type predicates and how are they created?
correct_answer: Type predicates are functions that return a boolean and have a return type `value is Type`. Used for custom type guards. Example: `function isString(value: unknown): value is string { return typeof value === "string"; }`.

question_text: What is the `typeof` type operator and how is it used?
correct_answer: `typeof` as a type operator gets the type of a value (variable
explanation: property). Example: `let x = 5; type X = typeof x;` → `number`. Useful for capturing types of constants or creating type aliases from values.

question_text: What is the `instanceof` type guard?
option_d: `instanceof` checks if an object is an instance of a class (or constructor function). It narrows the type in TypeScript. Example: `if (error instanceof Error) { ... }`. Works with classes
correct_answer: not interfaces.

question_text: What is the `in` operator type guard?
option_d: `in` operator checks if a property exists on an object. It narrows union types. Example: `if ("radius" in shape) { shape.radius }` (assuming `Shape` union). Useful for discriminating union types.
correct_answer: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/narrowing.html#the-in-operator-narrowing

question_text: What are literal types and how are they used?
correct_answer: number literal
mdn_link: or booleans: `let x: "hello" = "hello";`. Often used in unions: `type Direction = "left" | "right"`. Combined with `as const` to infer literals.

question_text: What are index signatures and when are they used?
correct_answer: Index signatures define types for dynamic property access: `interface Dictionary { [key: string]: number; }`. Allows any string key with number value. Can also use `number` or `symbol` as key type.

question_text: What are optional properties and how are they marked?
correct_answer: Optional properties may be missing: `interface Person { name?: string; }`. Type includes `undefined`. Use when property is not required. Different from union with `undefined`.

question_text: What are readonly properties in interfaces/objects?
option_d: `readonly` in interfaces makes properties immutable: `interface Point { readonly x: number; }`. Can only be assigned during creation. Similar to `readonly` in classes.
correct_answer: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/objects.html#readonly-properties

question_text: What are excess property checks and how do they work?
correct_answer: Excess property checks occur when assigning object literals to types. TypeScript errors if object has properties not in the target type. Avoid with type assertions

question_text: What are brand/nominal types and how can they be simulated?
correct_answer: Brand types create distinct types with same structure. Simulated using a private property: `type Brand<T
explanation: B> = T & { __brand: B };`. Example: `type UserId = Brand<string

question_text: What are recursive types and how are they defined?
option_d: Recursive types reference themselves: `type TreeNode = { value: number; children: TreeNode[]; }`. Interfaces can also be recursive. Useful for tree-like structures.
correct_answer: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/advanced-types.html#recursive-type-aliases

question_text: What are variance (covariance
correct_answer: covariance
mdn_link: Variance describes how subtyping relates with generics. TypeScript uses structural typing: functions are contravariant in parameters
youtube_english: covariant in return. Arrays are mutable
youtube_hindi: so invariant. Understanding variance helps with generic constraints.

question_text: What are mixins and how are they implemented in TypeScript?
correct_answer: Mixins are a pattern for composing classes. Implemented using helper functions that return a class extending a base. TypeScript supports mixins via class expressions and intersection types. Example: `applyMixins(Derived

question_text: What are decorators and how are they used in TypeScript?
correct_answer: Decorators (experimental) modify classes/methods at design time. Use `@decorator` syntax. Can be applied to class

question_text: What are constructor signatures and how are they typed?
correct_answer: Constructor signatures describe constructible types: `interface ClockConstructor { new (hour: number): Clock; }`. Used with `new` keyword. Useful for factory functions or class types.

question_text: What are call signatures and how are they typed?
correct_answer: Call signatures describe callable objects (like functions). In interfaces: `interface SearchFunc { (source: string): boolean; }`. Objects with call signatures can be called like functions.

question_text: What are `this` parameters in functions?
option_d: `this` parameters declare the expected type of `this` in a function: `function (this: HTMLElement) { ... }`. Helps catch incorrect calls. Does not affect runtime; used for type checking.
correct_answer: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/functions.html#declaring-this-in-a-function

question_text: What are generic constraints and how are they applied?
option_d: Generic constraints limit the types that can be used: `function logLength<T extends { length: number }>(arg: T)`. `T` must have a `length` property. Uses `extends` keyword.
correct_answer: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/generics.html#generic-constraints

question_text: What are default type parameters in generics?
option_d: Default type parameters provide a fallback: `interface Box<T = string> { value: T; }`. If not specified
correct_answer: `T` defaults to `string`. Similar to default function parameters.

question_text: What are generic classes and how are they used?
option_d: Generic classes have type parameters: `class Stack<T> { private items: T[] = []; }`. The type parameter can be used in methods and properties. Instance type is `Stack<number>`.
correct_answer: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/generics.html#generic-classes

question_text: What are generic interfaces and how are they used?
option_d: Generic interfaces have type parameters: `interface Pair<T
correct_answer: U> { first: T; second: U; }`. Used to describe objects with generic shape. Can have default type parameters.

question_text: What are mapped type modifiers (`+`
correct_answer: Mapped Type Modifiers
youtube_tamil: `-?`. Example: `type Mutable<T> = { -readonly [K in keyof T]: T[K]; }` removes readonly. `+` is default (adds modifier).

question_text: What are key remapping in mapped types?
correct_answer: Key remapping (TypeScript 4.1+) allows transforming keys: `{ [K in keyof T as NewKey]: T[K] }`. Can filter keys: `{ [K in keyof T as K extends "id" ? never : K]: T[K] }` removes `id`. Uses `as` clause.

question_text: What are conditional type inference with `infer`?
correct_answer: `infer` can infer multiple types: `type First<T> = T extends [infer U
explanation: ...unknown[]] ? U : never;`. Can infer in nested conditionals. Used to extract types from complex structures.

question_text: What are distributive conditional types?
option_d: Distributive conditional types distribute over union types: `type ToArray<T> = T extends any ? T[] : never;` with `ToArray<string | number>` becomes `string[] | number[]`. Disable distribution by wrapping in tuple: `[T] extends [any]`.
correct_answer: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/conditional-types.html#distributive-conditional-types

question_text: What are template literal type inference?
option_d: Template literal types can infer parts: `type Parse<T> = T extends `${infer Left}/${infer Right}` ? [Left
correct_answer: Right] : never;`. Extracts pattern matches. Useful for string parsing at type level.

question_text: What are intrinsic string manipulation types?
correct_answer: Capitalize
youtube_hindi: `Uncapitalize<S>`. They transform string literal types at compile time. Built-in

question_text: What are `Exclude` and `Extract` utility types?
correct_answer: `Exclude<T
explanation: U>` removes from `T` types assignable to `U`. `Extract<T
topic: U>` extracts from `T` types assignable to `U`. Built on conditional types. Useful for filtering union types.

question_text: What are `NonNullable` and `Parameters` utility types?
correct_answer: `NonNullable<T>` removes `null` and `undefined` from `T`. `Parameters<T>` extracts parameter types of a function type as a tuple. Other utility types: `ReturnType`

question_text: What are `Awaited` and `ThisParameterType` utility types?
correct_answer: `Awaited<T>` unwraps `Promise` (recursively). `ThisParameterType<T>` extracts `this` parameter type of a function. Other: `OmitThisParameter`

question_text: What are module resolution strategies in TypeScript?
correct_answer: node
explanation: TypeScript has two strategies: `classic` (old) and `node` (default). Node resolution mimics Node.js: looks in `node_modules`

question_text: What are path mapping and baseUrl in tsconfig?
correct_answer: `baseUrl` sets base directory for module resolution. `paths` maps import paths to locations: `{ "@/*": ["src/*"] }`. Allows absolute imports. Requires `baseUrl`. Used with module bundlers.

question_text: What are compiler options `strict`
correct_answer: strict
mdn_link: `strict` enables all strict type checking options. `noImplicitAny` errors on implied `any`. `strictNullChecks` requires handling `null`/`undefined`. Other strict options: `strictFunctionTypes`

question_text: What are `target`
correct_answer: target

question_text: What are declaration files generation options?
correct_answer: `declaration` generates `.d.ts` files. `declarationMap` generates sourcemaps for declarations. `emitDeclarationOnly` only emits declarations. Used for library publishing.

question_text: What are `skipLibCheck` and `forceConsistentCasingInFileNames` options?
correct_answer: `skipLibCheck` skips type checking of declaration files (speeds up compilation). `forceConsistentCasingInFileNames` ensures consistent file name casing (helps cross-platform). Other: `skipDefaultLibCheck`.

question_text: What are `esModuleInterop` and `allowSyntheticDefaultImports`?
correct_answer: `esModuleInterop` enables interoperability between CommonJS and ES modules (allows `import React from "react"`). `allowSyntheticDefaultImports` allows default imports from modules with no default export (type-checking only).

question_text: What are `incremental` and `composite` compiler options?
correct_answer: `incremental` saves compiler state for faster subsequent builds. `composite` enables project references (building multiple projects). Requires `tsconfig.json` with `references`. Used in monorepos.

question_text: What are project references and how are they configured?
correct_answer: Project references allow splitting codebase into smaller projects. In `tsconfig.json`: `{ "references": [{ "path": "../shared" }] }`. Build with `tsc --build`. Each project has own config.

question_text: What are `noEmit`
correct_answer: noEmit
mdn_link: no output. `noEmitOnError` prevents emit if errors. `emitDeclarationOnly` only emits `.d.ts`. Useful for different build scenarios.

question_text: What are `isolatedModules` and `verbatimModuleSyntax`?
correct_answer: `isolatedModules` ensures each file can be transpiled independently (required for Babel). `verbatimModuleSyntax` (TypeScript 5.0+) preserves import/export syntax exactly as written (no elision).

question_text: What are `exactOptionalPropertyTypes` and `noUncheckedIndexedAccess`?
correct_answer: `exactOptionalPropertyTypes` makes optional properties not include `undefined`. `noUncheckedIndexedAccess` adds `undefined` to indexed access (`obj[key]`). Both are strict options for more safety.

question_text: What are `useDefineForClassFields` and `useUnknownInCatchVariables`?
correct_answer: `useDefineForClassFields` uses ECMAScript standard class field semantics. `useUnknownInCatchVariables` types catch variables as `unknown` (default in strict mode). Modernizes behavior.

question_text: What are `moduleDetection` and `resolveJsonModule`?
correct_answer: `moduleDetection` controls how TypeScript detects files as modules. `resolveJsonModule` allows importing JSON files as modules (requires `esModuleInterop`).

question_text: What is the `tsc` command and its common flags?
correct_answer: `tsc` is the TypeScript compiler. Flags: `--watch` (watch mode)

question_text: What are source maps and how are they generated?
correct_answer: Source maps map compiled JavaScript back to TypeScript source for debugging. Options: `sourceMap`

question_text: What are declaration maps and how are they used?
option_d: Declaration maps map `.d.ts` declarations back to source `.ts` for library consumers. Enable "Go to Definition" to original source. Option: `declarationMap`.
correct_answer: https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig#declarationMap

question_text: What are custom type definitions and how are they written?
correct_answer: Writing custom type definitions: create `.d.ts` file
topic: `export` for modules. Example: `declare module "my-module" { export function foo(): string; }`. Can augment existing types.

question_text: What is the `globalThis` type and how is it used?
option_d: `globalThis` is the global object in all environments. TypeScript has `globalThis` type representing the global scope. Can be augmented: `declare global { interface GlobalThis { myVar: string; } }`.
correct_answer: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/release-notes/typescript-3-4.html#type-checking-for-globalthis

correct_answer: This is the 100th intermediate-level TypeScript question
